title: Rio Olympic venues already trashed, abandoned
text:
Rio Olympic venues already trashed, abandoned  38pm by Melanie Dinjaski with AP, AFP Source: FOX SPORTS JUST six months after the Rio Games concluded, numerous venues where Olympic events were held have become run-down and deserted. 
Recent photos taken around Brazil by AFP photojournalist Yasuyoshi Chiba and AP photojournalist Silvia Izquierdo show the eerie scene at former Olympic venues. 
“It’s not a good look for us. There’s no doubt about that,” International Olympic Committee vice president John Coates told Around The Rings . 
“We wanted the venues to be used, to be a legacy for those [permanent arenas] that were to stay.” The outside cover of the Olympic Aquatic Stadium is falling off. AFP PHOTO / Yasuyoshi Chiba. Source: AFP View of the Tennis Court at the Olympic Park after it was covered by sand to be used for beach volley ball. AFP PHOTO / Yasuyoshi Chiba. Source: AFP View of the Olympic Velodrome at the Olympic Park. AFP PHOTO / Yasuyoshi Chiba. Source: AFP View inside the Carioca Arena 2, which hosted wrestling and judo has scattered construction equipment. AFP PHOTO / Yasuyoshi Chiba. Source: AFP Carioca Arena 2 has concrete blocks in doorways. AFP PHOTO / Yasuyoshi Chiba. Source: AFP 
In Barra, the once bustling athletes village high-rise apartments now resemble a ghost town, completely abandoned. 
The Macarena stadium that received over $370 million for renovations for the 2014 World Cup and 2016 Rio Games is now covered in dead grass and rusted (and missing) seating. 
Tapestries by artist Adriana Varejao covering the outside of the Olympic Aquatic Stadium are scattered around the ground having fallen off with no-one to maintain them. 
In north Rio, the canoe slalom was supposed to become a massive swimming pool for local residents to cool off in the hot Brazilian summers, but that remains closed. 
The Olympic Park is only open to the public to walk around on the weekends, but with not much else offered, many of the facilities are vacant and in a state of disrepair. 
According to an AFP report , the Arena of the Future was meant to become the site of four schools with up to 500 students in each, but that hasn’t happened yet either. 
In the lead-up to the Games, hundreds of people from poor communities like Vila Autodromo were forced to relocate and make way for construction around the Olympic Park. View of the world-famous Maracana Stadium in Rio de Janeiro on January 18, 2017. After playing a key role in the 2014 World Cup and 2016 Olympic Games, iconic Maracana Stadium has fallen into a state of abandon due to a contract dispute, and is closed to tourists. AFP PHOTO / VANDERLEI ALMEIDA Source: AFP In this February 2, 2017 photo, a trash can lays by ripped seats at one of the dugouts in Maracana stadium. AP Photo / Silvia Izquierdo. Source: AP Maracana stadium was hit by vandals who ripped out thousands of seats and stole televisions. AP Photo / Silvia Izquierdo. Source: AP Nobs are left where seats were ripped out at Maracana stadium. AP Photo / Silvia Izquierdo. Source: AP Carioca Arena 2. Rio's Olympic organisers promised there'd be ‘no white elephants’. AFP PHOTO / Yasuyoshi Chiba. Source: AFP View after part of the upper seats were removed from the Carioca Arena 1, which hosted basketball. AFP PHOTO / Yasuyoshi Chiba. Source: AFP 
“I hope that they find a way of bringing people to it to utilise those venues,” Coates said. 
Coates blamed the government for struggling with the transition since the Games concluded. Private companies are steering clear of investing in the sites and the state budget is still recovering from exceeding estimated spending on the Games, leaving these sporting venues neglected. 
“It can happen because of the financial situation with the city council, and not having put in place companies to manage these venues afterwards. It’s local planning,” Coates said. 
Of the 17 new venues constructed for the Rio Games, 10 were meant to be repurposed for future use, however it remains to be seen when this will happen. A stolen TV inside Maracana stadium in Rio. AP Photo / Silvia Izquierdo. Source: AP This Feb. 2, 2017 photo shows seats jumbled in a pile inside Maracana stadium. The historic stadium, site of the opening and closing ceremony, has been vandalised as stadium operators, the Rio state government, and Olympic organisers, have fought over $1 million in unpaid electricity bills and management of the venue. AP Photo / Silvia Izquierdo. Source: AP Luxury apartments known as "Riserva Golf," off the Olympic golf course in Rio de Janeiro, which won't be completed until 2018. In a deal with the city, billionaire developer Pasquale Mauro spent about $20 million to build the course in exchange for permission to construct the multimillion-dollar apartments on some of Rio's most desirable real estate. AP Photo / Silvia Izquierdo. Source: AP In this Feb. 4, 2017 photo, children play near the Olympic Park sign. Rio organisers still owe creditors about $40 million. Four of the new arenas in the main Olympic Park have failed to find a private-sector management, and ownership has passed to the federal government. Another new arena will be run by the cash-strapped city. AP Photo / Silvia Izquierdo. Source: AP Sign up for Sportsmail The latest sports news, in your inbox daily. Email
